Assignment 1 2 ∑ Max. points 10 10 20 Your points Formal Methods and Functional Programming, Quiz 1, SS20 2 Assignment 1: Natural Deduction (10 points) Recall the following rules for natural deduction in ﬁrst-order intuitionistic logic: Γ, A Ø A axiom Γ, A Ø B Γ Ø A → B →I Γ Ø A → B Γ Ø A Γ Ø B →E Γ Ø Œ Γ Ø A ŒE Γ, A Ø Œ Γ Ø ¬A ¬I Γ Ø ¬A Γ Ø A Γ Ø B ¬E Γ Ø A Γ Ø B Γ Ø A ∧ B ∧I Γ Ø A ∧ B Γ Ø A ∧EL Γ Ø A ∧ B Γ Ø B ∧ER Γ Ø A Γ Ø A ∨ B ∨IL Γ Ø B Γ Ø A ∨ B ∨IR Γ Ø A ∨ B Γ, A Ø C Γ, B Ø C Γ Ø C ∨E Γ Ø A Γ Ø ∀x. A ∀I ∗ Γ Ø ∀x. A Γ Ø A[x~t] ∀E Γ Ø A[x~t] Γ Ø ∃x. A ∃I Γ Ø ∃x. A Γ, A Ø B Γ Ø B ∃E ∗∗ Side conditions: (∗) x is not free in any formula in Γ, (∗∗) x is neither free in B nor in any formula in Γ. Prove using the above rules that ›(∃x. p(x)) → ∀y. ¬q(y)” → (∀x. p(x)) → ¬∃y. q(y) is a tautology. Give a complete derivation tree and label each inference step with the name of the corresponding rule. Formal Methods and Functional Programming, Quiz 1, SS20 3 Solution: Let • Γ1 ∶= (∃x. p(x)) → ∀y. ¬q(y) • Γ2 ∶= Γ1, ∀x. p(x) • Γ3 ∶= Γ2, ∃y. q(y) • Γ4 ∶= Γ3, q(y) Γ3 Ø ∃y. q(y) axiom Γ4 Ø (∃x. p(x)) → ∀y. ¬q(y) axiom Γ4 Ø ∀x. p(x) axiom Γ4 Ø p(x) ∀E Γ4 Ø ∃x. p(x) ∃I Γ4 Ø ∀y. ¬q(y) →E Γ4 Ø ¬q(y) ∀E Γ4 Ø q(y) axiom Γ4 Ø Œ ¬E Γ3 Ø Œ ∃E ∗∗ Γ2 Ø ¬∃y. q(y) ¬I Γ1 Ø (∀x. p(x)) → ¬∃y. q(y) →I Ø ›(∃x. p(x)) → ∀y. ¬q(y)” → (∀x. p(x)) → ¬∃y. q(y) →I (∗∗): y is neither free in Œ nor in Γ3 (as every occurence of y is bound by a quantiﬁer) Formal Methods and Functional Programming, Quiz 1, SS20 4 Assignment 2: Digits in Base Nine (10 points) Every integer n ≥ 1 has a unique representation in base 9. That is, there exists a unique sequence n = d0, d1, d2, . . . , dm of integers in {0, 1, . . . , 8} such that n = ∑0≤i≤m di ⋅ 9i and dm ≠ 0. We call di the ith digit of n in base 9. For example: 19 = 1, 2 19 = 1 ⋅ 90 + 2 ⋅ 91 256 = 4, 1, 3 256 = 4 ⋅ 90 + 1 ⋅ 91 + 3 ⋅ 92 2020 = 4, 8, 6, 2 2020 = 4 ⋅ 90 + 8 ⋅ 91 + 6 ⋅ 92 + 2 ⋅ 93 12345 = 6, 3, 8, 7, 1 12345 = 6 ⋅ 90 + 3 ⋅ 91 + 8 ⋅ 92 + 7 ⋅ 93 + 1 ⋅ 94 Write a Haskell function digitSum :: Int -> Int -> Int such that digitSum n k computes the sum of the ﬁrst k ≥ 0 digits of n in base 9, that is, it computes ∑0≤i≤k−1 di. You may assume that n has at least k digits in base 9. Note: This task can be solved without using lists. Examples: digitSum 19 0 = 0 digitSum 256 2 = 5 digitSum 2020 3 = 18 digitSum 12345 5 = 25 Solution: digitSum :: Int -> Int -> Int digitSum n 0 = 0 digitSum n k = (n `mod` 9) + digitSum (n `div` 9) (k - 1)
